a curved device that a person who has lost part of a leg can attach to their body where the leg was, in order to be able to walk or run, for example in a race
blade.eg: The blades, made from lightweight carbon fibre, store kinetic energy in a similar fashion to a spring and allow the athlete to run and jump.

blade.eng_def: an attractive and confident young man
blade.chi_def: 有吸引力、自信的年輕男子

blame.eng_def: to say or think that someone or something did something wrong or is responsible for something bad happening
blame.eg: Don't blame me (= it is not my fault) if you miss the bus!

blame.eng_def: said in order to tell someone that you understand why they are doing something and that you agree with the reason for doing it
blame.chi_def: 我不會怪…；我理解…的心情
blame.eg: I don't blame him for getting angry - she's being really annoying.

blame.eng_def: to be the reason for something that happens
blame.eg: The hot weather is partly to blame for the water shortage.

blame.eng_def: the situation in which people say or think that someone or something did something wrong or is responsible for something bad happening
blame.eg: Health officials put the blame for the disease on (= say that the reason for the disease is) poor housing conditions.

blame.eng_def: If you take the blame for something, you say that you did it or that it is your fault.
blame.eg: If anything goes wrong, I'll take the blame.

blank.eng_def: empty or clear, or containing no information or mark
showing no understanding or no emotion in the expression on your face
a space in a piece of writing or on a form, left empty for information to be added
blank.eg: Fill in the blanks on this form.

blank.eng_def: something not yet drawn or finished, such as a key not yet cut into a finished shape
a small tube containing explosive but no bullet, used in a gun in order to make a loud noise without causing harm

blanket.eng_def: a flat cover made of wool or similar warm material, usually used on a bed
including or affecting everything, everyone, or all cases, in a large group or area
blanket.chi_def: 適用於任何情況的；總括的，綜合的

blanket.eng_def: to cover something completely with a thick layer
blanket.eg: Outside the fields were blanketed in fog.

blast.eng_def: to explode or destroy something or someone with explosives, or to break through or hit something with a similar, very strong force
blast.eg: A tunnel was to be blasted through the mountains.

blast.eng_def: to make a very loud and unpleasant noise
blast.chi_def: 産生巨大噪聲；發出刺耳聲

blast.eng_def: to criticize someone or something severely
blast.eg: The administration was blasted for failing to create jobs.
Three people were injured in the blast.

blast.eng_def: a sudden strong blow of air
blast.chi_def: 疾風，狂風；一陣強勁的氣流
blast.eg: A blast of cold air hit him as he opened the window.

blast.eng_def: an exciting or enjoyable experience or event, often a party
blast.eg: You should have come with us last night - we had a real blast!

blast.eng_def: an email sent by a company or organization to a large number of people
blast.chi_def: （公司、組織等傳發的）群發電子郵件
blast.eg: He announced in an email blast to supporters that he is suspending his campaign.
Oh blast! I've left my keys at home!

blaze.eg: The sun was blazing down that afternoon.

blaze.eng_def: to be brightly lit or full of colour
blaze.eg: Isaac's eyes suddenly blazed with anger.

blaze.eng_def: When a gun or a person using a gun blazes, the gun fires and continues firing.
blaze.eg: The ship's guns blazed at the British as they tried to run for shore.
Firefighters took two hours to control the blaze.

blaze.eng_def: something that has a very powerful or noticeable effect
blaze.eg: The garden is a blaze of colour in autumn.

blaze.eng_def: a white mark on the face of a horse or other animal

bleach.eng_def: a strong chemical used for cleaning things or removing colour from things
to remove the colour from something or make it lighter, with the use of chemicals or by the effect of light from the sun; to become lighter in this way
bleach.chi_def: 漂白；使褪色；使色彩變淡

bleak.eng_def: If a place is bleak, it is empty, and not welcoming or attractive.
bleak.eg: The house stands on a bleak, windswept hilltop.

bleak.eng_def: Bleak weather is cold and unpleasant.
If a situation is bleak, there is little or no hope for the future.

bleed.eng_def: (in the past) to make someone lose blood, as a cure for an illness
If you bleed a closed system such as a radiator or a brake, you remove air or liquid from it to make it work correctly.
bleed.chi_def: 把…抽乾，放掉…中的空氣（或液體）

blend.eng_def: a mixture of different things or styles
blend.chi_def: （不同東西或風格的）混合品，混合物
blend.eg: a rich blend of the finest coffee beans
Blend the ingredients into a smooth paste.

bless.eng_def: to ask for God's help and protection for someone or something, or to call or make someone or something holy
bless.chi_def: 求上帝降福於；祝福；使神聖

blessing.eng_def: a request by a priest for God to take care of a particular person or a group of people, or God's act of doing this
blessing.eg: The mass always ends with a blessing.

blessing.eng_def: something that is extremely lucky or makes you happy
blessing.eg: It was a blessing that no one was killed in the accident.

blessing.eng_def: approval that someone gives to a plan or action
blessing.eg: The committee has given its blessing to the plan.

blind.eng_def: used to describe an extreme feeling that happens without thought or reason
to not be conscious of something or to refuse to notice something that is obvious to others
blind.chi_def: 沒有注意到…；對…視而不見
blind.eg: She seems blind to his faults.

blind.eng_def: that a driver cannot see or cannot see around
blind.chi_def: （司機看不到的）盲點的，盲區的
blind.eg: The accident happened on a blind bend.

blind.eng_def: used to refer to a scientific test in which either the people being tested or the person testing them, or both, do not know what is being tested
blind.chi_def: （科學實驗中，測試人和/或被測人不知測試內容的）盲測
blind.eg: In blind trials, users who were given both drugs orally were unable to distinguish between the effects of heroin and methadone.

blind.eng_def: to make someone unable to see, permanently or for a short time
blind.eg: She was blinded in an accident at an early age.

blind.eng_def: to make someone unable to notice or understand something
blind.eg: We shouldn't let our prejudices blind us to the facts of the situation.

blind.eng_def: a cover for a window made of a single piece or strips of cloth, paper, or plastic that is pulled up or down by a string
people who are unable to see
blind.eg: She trains dogs for the blind.

blind.eng_def: a place where people can watch wild animals or birds without being noticed by them
blind.chi_def: （可以觀察野獸或鳥類的）隱藏處，躲藏處

blind.eng_def: If something or someone is tested blind, either the people being tested or the person testing them, or both, do not know what is being tested.
blind.chi_def: （科學實驗中，測試人和/或被測人不知測試內容的）用盲測方法做…地

blind.eng_def: to be flying an aircraft somewhere without being able to see where you are going
blind.chi_def: 飛行時無法看到方向，盲飛；僅靠儀錶飛行
blind.eg: He admitted dazzling a police helicopter pilot with a laser beam, leaving the pilot flying blind.

blind.eng_def: to be doing something without having any experience of doing it before or without having important information about what you are doing
blind.chi_def: 沒有任何經驗或資訊就開始做一件事，盲目行事
blind.eg: They are flying blind on this issue because they have no idea of the extent of the problem.

blink.eng_def: When you blink, you close and then open your eyes quickly once or several times, and when an eye blinks, it does this.
blink.eg: You've got something in your eye - try blinking a few times.

blink.eng_def: If a light blinks, it flashes on and off.

blizzard.eng_def: a severe snow storm with strong winds
blizzard.eg: We once got stuck in a blizzard for six hours.

blizzard.eng_def: a large amount of something that arrives or is produced together in a confusing or badly organized way

block.eng_def: the distance along a street from where one road crosses it to the place where the next road crosses it, or one part of a street like this, especially in a town or city
block.eg: The museum is just six blocks away.

block.eng_def: a square group of buildings or houses with roads on each side
block.eg: I took a walk around the block.

block.eng_def: on the next street that crosses this street
block.chi_def: 在前面轉過去的那條街上
block.eg: He lives just around the block.

block.eng_def: a solid, straight-sided piece of hard material
(in the past) a large piece of wood on which criminals had their head cut off
block.eg: Anne Boleyn went to (= was killed on) the block.

block.eng_def: a large, usually tall building divided into separate parts for use as offices or homes by several different organizations or people
a group of things bought, dealt with, or considered together
something that blocks a tube or opening
block.eg: A block in (= an object blocking) the pipe was preventing the water from coming through.
A fallen tree is blocking the road.

block.eng_def: to be between someone and the thing they are looking at, so that they cannot see
block.eg: My view was blocked by a tall man in front of me.

block.eng_def: to stop something from happening or succeeding
block.eg: She was very talented and I felt her parents were blocking her progress.

blond.eng_def: with pale yellow or gold hair
blond.chi_def: 淺黃色頭髮的；金色頭髮的

blond.eng_def: a woman with pale yellow or gold hair
blond.eg: Who's the blonde talking to Bob?

blonde.eng_def: with pale yellow or gold hair
blonde.chi_def: 淺黃色頭髮的；金色頭髮的

blonde.eng_def: a woman with pale yellow or gold hair
blonde.eg: Who's the blonde talking to Bob?

blood.eng_def: the red liquid that is sent around the body by the heart, and carries oxygen and important substances to organs and tissue, and removes waste products
blood.eg: He lost a lot of blood in the accident.

blood.eng_def: to allow a trained person to take some blood from your body so that it can be stored and is ready to be given to people who have lost a lot of blood in an accident or operation
family relationship by birth rather than marriage
to give someone their first experience of something
blood.eg: They decided to blood him in the international team at the age of only 18.

bloody.eng_def: used to express anger or to emphasize what you are saying in a slightly rude way
bloody.eg: I've had a bloody awful week.

bloody.eng_def: covered with or full of blood
extremely violent and involving a lot of blood and injuries
bloody.eg: It was a long and bloody battle and many men were killed.
The first punch bloodied his nose.

bloom.eng_def: When a flower blooms, it opens or is open, and when a plant or tree blooms it produces flowers.
bloom.eg: These flowers will bloom all through the summer.
The apple trees are in full bloom (= completely covered in flowers).
The roses are just coming into bloom.
He was 19, in the full bloom of youth.

blossom.eng_def: When a tree or plant blossoms, it produces flowers before producing fruit that can be eaten.
blossom.eg: The cherry tree is beginning to blossom.

blossom.eng_def: When people blossom, they become more attractive, successful, or confident, and when good feelings or relationships blossom, they develop and become stronger.
blossom.chi_def: （人）變得更有魅力（或更成功、更自信）；（好的感覺或關係）深入發展，增強

blossom.eng_def: a small flower, or the small flowers on a tree or plant

blot.eng_def: a small area of ink made by mistake
to dry a wet surface, or writing done in ink, by pressing something soft against it
blot.eg: I signed my name and blotted the paper.

blot.eng_def: to make a blot or blots on something

blouse.eng_def: a shirt for a woman or girl

blow.eng_def: to move and make currents of air, or to be moved or make something move on a current of air
blow.eg: The wind was blowing harder every minute.

blow.eng_def: to make a sound by forcing air out of your mouth and through an instrument, or to make a sound when someone does this
blow.eg: Ann blew a few notes on the trumpet.

blow.eng_def: to blow air down a tube into a piece of heated soft glass, in order to shape it into an object
to force air from your lungs and through your nose to clear it
to kiss your hand and blow on it in the direction of someone
to cause something to be destroyed by a bomb, technical failure, etc.
blow.eg: His car had been blown to pieces.

blow.eng_def: If an electrical fuse (= a short, thin piece of wire) blows, or if something electrical blows a fuse, the device it is in stops working because it is receiving too much electricity.
If a tyre blows, it suddenly gets a hole in it and goes flat.
to seriously damage something by making it explode
blow.eg: The explosion blew the building sky-high.

blow.eng_def: to spend a large amount of money, especially on things that are not really necessary
blow.eg: When I got paid I blew it all on a night out.

blow.eng_def: a hard hit with a hand or a weapon
blow.eg: a sharp blow to the stomach

blow.eng_def: an unexpected event that has a damaging effect on someone or something
blow.eg: Losing his job was a severe blow to his confidence.

blow.eng_def: a walk in the fresh air
blow.eg: Shall we go out for a blow?

blue.eng_def: of the colour of the sky without clouds on a bright day, or a darker or lighter type of this
blue.chi_def: 藍色的；天藍色的；青藍色的

blue.eng_def: showing or mentioning sexual activity in a way that offends many people

blue.eg: He's been a bit blue since she left him.

blue.eng_def: (of meat) cooked so that it is still very red
a person who has played a sport for Oxford University against Cambridge University or for Cambridge University against Oxford University, or the title given to him or her for this
blue.chi_def: 牛津（或劍橋）大學校隊運動員（頭銜）

blues.eng_def: a type of slow, sad music, originally from the southern US, in which the singer typically sings about their difficult life or bad luck in love
blues.chi_def: 藍調（一種曲調憂傷的慢節奏音樂，源自美國南部，主要以歌手的困苦生活或愛情不幸為演唱內容）
blues.eg: Billie Holiday was famous for singing the blues.

blunder.eng_def: a serious mistake, usually caused by not taking care or thinking
blunder.chi_def: （通常由於粗心或欠考慮而釀成的）大錯
blunder.eg: He said that the tax was a major political blunder.

blunder.eng_def: to move in an awkward way
blunder.chi_def: 跌跌撞撞地走，踉踉蹌蹌地走
blunder.eg: I could hear him blundering around in the darkness.

blunder.eng_def: to make a serious mistake, usually because of not taking care or thinking
blunder.eg: Police blundered by not releasing more details about the case to focus public interest.

blunt.eng_def: A blunt pencil, knife, etc. is not sharp and therefore not able to write, cut, etc. well.
saying what you think without trying to be polite or considering other people's feelings
blunt.chi_def: 直率的；生硬的；直截了當的
blunt.eg: I'll be blunt - that last piece of work you did was terrible.

blunt.eng_def: to make a feeling less strong

blunt.eng_def: a large cigarette or cigar containing the drug cannabis

blur.eng_def: something that you cannot see clearly

blur.eng_def: something that you cannot remember or understand clearly
blur.chi_def: 記不清的東西；理解不清楚的東西

blush.eng_def: to become pink in the face, usually from embarrassment

blush.eng_def: a pink colour in the face, usually from embarrassment
blush.eg: A blush of shame crept up his face.

board.eng_def: a thin, flat piece of cut wood or other hard material, often used for a particular purpose

board.eng_def: a flat piece of wood or other hard material with a special pattern on it, used for playing games

board.eg: The teacher wrote her name up on the board.
I stuck the notice (up) on the board.
I dived off the top board today, Dad.

board.eng_def: the wooden fence surrounding the ice surface in ice hockey
the group of people who are responsible for controlling and organizing a company or organization

board.eng_def: an official examination given by some medical and business organizations in the US
board.chi_def: （美國某些醫療、商業組織舉行的）執業考試

board.eng_def: on a boat, train, or aircraft

board.eng_def: meals provided when you are staying somewhere, usually for money
board.chi_def: （住宿處提供的）伙食，膳食（通常需付費）

board.eng_def: to get onto or allow people to get onto a boat, train, or aircraft

board.eng_def: to pay to sleep and eat meals in someone's house

board.eng_def: to sleep and eat at school during the school term

board.eng_def: to arrange for a pet animal to be temporarily taken care of at a place other than its home

boast.eng_def: to speak too proudly or happily about what you have done or what you own

boast.eng_def: to have or own something to be proud of

boast.eng_def: something you are proud of and like to tell people about
boast.eg: It is her proud boast that she has never missed a single episode of the show.

boat.eng_def: a small vehicle for travelling on water

boat.eg: Are you travelling by boat or by air?

bodily.eng_def: If you lift or carry someone bodily, you lift or carry them in your arms.
bodily.eg: He carried her bodily up the stairs.

body.eng_def: the whole physical structure that forms a person or animal

body.eng_def: the main part of a person's or animal's body, without the head, or without the head, arms, and legs
body.eg: He had a fat body but thin legs and arms.

body.eng_def: the painted metal shell of a vehicle, such as a car or an aircraft

body.eng_def: a piece of tight-fitting women's clothing that covers the top half of the body and fastens between the legs
body.chi_def: （女子上半身穿的）連體緊身內衣

body.chi_def: （以正式或官方的方式）全體一致地；一起地

body.eng_def: the main part of a large building

bog.eng_def: soft, wet ground, or an area of this

boil.eng_def: to reach, or cause something to reach, the temperature at which a liquid starts to turn into a gas

boil.eng_def: to heat a container, especially one used for cooking, until the liquid in it starts to turn into a gas
to cook food by putting it in water that is boiling

boil.eng_def: If a container or food boils dry, all the liquid in the container in which the food was cooking turns to gas.

a painful swelling on the skin that is filled with pus (= thick, yellow liquid)
the act of washing or cooking something in very hot water

boil.eg: Bring the water to the boil, then add the pasta.

bold.eg: She was a bold and fearless climber.

bold.eng_def: strong in colour or shape, and very noticeable to the eye

bold.eng_def: not shy, especially in a way that shows no respect

bolt.eng_def: a metal bar on a door or window that slides across to lock it closed

bolt.eng_def: a screw-like metal object without a point, used with a nut to fasten things together
a flash of lightning that looks like a white line against the sky

bolt.eng_def: a length or roll of cloth or wallpaper
a type of short arrow shot from a crossbow (= a type of weapon)

bolt.eng_def: to move very fast, especially as a result of being frightened
bolt.chi_def: （尤指因受到驚嚇而）奔跑，快跑

bomb.eng_def: a weapon that explodes and is used to kill or hurt people or to damage buildings

bomb.eng_def: to destroy something by exploding a bomb inside it

bomb.eng_def: to travel very fast in a vehicle

bombard.eg: The troops bombarded the city, killing and injuring hundreds.

bond.eng_def: a close connection joining two or more people
an official paper given by the government or a company to show that you have lent them money that they will pay back to you at a particular interest rate
bond.eg: I invested some money in savings bonds.

bond.eng_def: an amount of money that is paid to formally promise that someone accused of a crime and being kept in prison will appear for trial if released

book.eng_def: a written text that can be published in printed or electronic form

one of the parts that a very long book, such as the Bible, is divided into
a number of one type of thing fastened together flat inside a cover

book.eng_def: the written records of money that a business has spent or received

boom.eng_def: a deep and loud hollow sound

boom.eng_def: a period of sudden economic growth, especially one that results in a lot of money being made

boom.eng_def: an increase in something , or a time when something becomes more popular

a long pole with a microphone on one end that is held above the actors so that it records their voices but cannot be seen by the people watching, used in television and film-making

border.eng_def: the line that divides one country from another

border.eng_def: a strip that goes around or along the edge of something, often as decoration

a very large wave that runs from the sea up a narrow river at particular times of year

born.eng_def: to come out of a mother's body, and start to exist

born in the way, place, or order mentioned

bosom.eng_def: used to describe a woman with large breasts

bottom.eng_def: the lower part of a piece of clothing that consists of two parts

bounce.eng_def: the act of bouncing, or the quality that makes something able to bounce

bound.eng_def: to move quickly with large jumping movements
to mark or form the limits of

bound.eng_def: past simple and past participle of bind

bound.eng_def: used to describe a book that is covered or held together in the stated way
used to describe clothes or other objects that have edges covered in the stated way

boundary.eng_def: the limit of a subject or principle

bout.eng_def: a short period of illness or involvement in an activity
bout.chi_def: （疾病的）發作；（某活動的）一段，一陣，一場

bow.eng_def: to bend your head or body forward, especially as a way of showing someone respect or expressing thanks to people who have watched you perform
the movement of bending your head or body forward, especially as a way of showing someone respect or expressing thanks to people who have watched you perform

bow.eng_def: the front part of a ship
a knot with two curved parts and two loose ends, used as a decoration or to tie shoes

bow.eng_def: a weapon for shooting arrows, made of a long, thin piece of wood bent into a curve by a tightly stretched string
a long, thin piece of wood with hair from the tail of a horse stretched along it, used to play musical instruments that have strings

bowl.eng_def: a large bowl-shaped building or structure, used for important sports events or musical performances

bowl.eng_def: a game played either outside on smooth grass or inside on an artificial surface, in which the players roll a large black or brown ball as close as possible to a smaller white ball

bowl.eng_def: a large ball used in the game of bowls

to throw a ball towards a batsman (= the player who hits the ball) using a vertical circular movement of the arm while running

box.eng_def: a square or rectangular container with stiff sides and sometimes a lid
a box and its contents, or just the contents of a box

box.eng_def: a piece of hard plastic worn by men to protect their sex organs when playing a sport
any square or rectangular space on a form, sports field, road, etc., separated from the main area by lines

box.eng_def: a place where two roads cross, marked with a square of yellow lines painted in the centre, that you can drive over only when the road in front is clear

box.eng_def: a box with a number in a post office to which your letters can be sent and from which you can collect them
a small evergreen tree (= one that never loses its leaves) with small, shiny leaves
to fight someone in the sport of boxing
box.eg: He used to box every weekend.

box.eng_def: to put something in a box
box.chi_def: 把…裝箱，把…置於箱（或盒子）內
box.eg: I boxed up some clothes and books to donate to charity.

boxer.eng_def: someone who takes part in the sport of boxing
boxer.eg: He was a heavyweight boxer before he became an actor.

boxer.eng_def: a dog of medium size with short, light brown hair and a short, flat nose
boxer.chi_def: 拳師狗（中等大小的短毛狗，毛色淺褐，鼻子短平）

boxing.eng_def: a sport in which two competitors fight by hitting each other with their hands
boxing.eg: Many doctors believe that boxing is too dangerous and should be banned.

boy.eng_def: a male child or, more generally, a male of any age

boy.eg: He used to like spending Friday nights with the boys.

boy.eng_def: an approving way of speaking about your country's soldiers
boy.chi_def: （對本國士兵的暱稱）子弟兵，士兵們
boy.eg: We must not forget our boys serving far from home.
He plays baseball, drinks a lot of beer and generally acts like one of the boys.

boy.eng_def: used to express excitement, worry, disappointment, etc. or to emphasize something

boycott.eng_def: to refuse to buy a product or take part in an activity as a way of expressing strong disapproval
boycott.chi_def: 拒絶購買（或參加）；抵制，杯葛
boycott.eg: People were urged to boycott the country's products.

boyhood.eng_def: the period when a person is a boy, and not yet a man, or the state of being a boy
boyhood.eg: I had a very happy boyhood.

bra.eng_def: a piece of women's underwear that supports the breasts

brace.eng_def: something that is used to support or connect things, or to make something stronger
brace.eg: He was recently fitted with a brace for his bad back.

brace.eng_def: a set of connected wires that is attached to a person's teeth in order to make them straight
brace.eg: I had to wear a brace for my crooked teeth when I was a teenager.

brace.eng_def: a pair of narrow straps that stretch from the front of the trousers over your shoulders to the back to hold them up
metal supports that are fastened to the legs of people who have difficulties with walking
brace.chi_def: （固定在腿部，協助行走的）腿部金屬支撐物

brace.eng_def: two things of the same type, especially two wild birds that have been killed for sport or food
brace.chi_def: （尤指獵獲的野鳥的）一雙，一對

brace.eng_def: to support an object in order to stop it from falling down
brace.eg: The side wall of the old house was braced with a wooden support.

brace.eng_def: to prepare yourself physically or mentally for something unpleasant
brace.chi_def: （為困難或壞事）使防備；使作準備
brace.eg: The passengers were told to brace themselves (= to press their bodies hard against something or hold them very stiff) for a crash landing.

bracelet.eng_def: a piece of jewellery that is worn around the wrist or arm

braid.eng_def: a thin strip of cloth or twisted threads that is attached to clothes, uniforms, or other things made of cloth, as a decoration
braid.eg: The captain of the ship wore a cap decorated with gold braid (= twisted gold threads).

braid.eng_def: a length of hair or other material that is divided into three parts that are then crossed over each other in a special pattern
braid.eg: She usually wears her hair in a braid/in two braids.

braid.eng_def: to join three or more pieces of hair or string-like material by putting them over each other in a special pattern

brain.eng_def: the organ inside the head that controls thought, memory, feelings, and activity
brain.eg: Doctors tried desperately to reduce the swelling in her brain.
Marie has an amazing brain (= is very intelligent).

brain.eng_def: a very intelligent person, especially one who has spent a lot of time studying
brain.eg: We have the best brains in the land working on this problem.

brain.eng_def: the most intelligent person in a group, especially the person who plans what the group will do
brain.chi_def: （機構組織中主管全域的）最聰明的人；策劃組織者
brain.eg: My little brother's the brains of the family.

brain.eng_def: to hit someone on the head
brain.eg: I'll brain you if you don't keep quiet.

brake.eng_def: a device that makes a vehicle go slower or stop, or a pedal, bar, or handle that makes this device work
brake.eg: She had no brakes on her bicycle.

brake.eng_def: the loud, unpleasant noise of a car suddenly stopping
brake.eg: Suddenly we heard a screech of brakes and saw the car swerve to miss the bicycle.

brake.eng_def: to make a vehicle go slower or stop, using its brake or brakes

branch.eg: Immunology is a branch of biological science.

branch.eng_def: one of the offices or groups that form part of a large business organization
branch.chi_def: 分支機構；分部；分行；分店
branch.eg: I used to work in the local branch of a large bank.

branch.eng_def: one of the parts of a tree that grows out from the main trunk and has leaves, flowers, or fruit on it
a part of a river or road that leaves the main part
branch.eg: This branch of the river eventually empties into the Atlantic.

branch.eng_def: a smaller blood vessel or nerve that grows out of the main part

branch.eg: The top of the tree had been cut off to encourage it to branch (out) lower down.
The road branches at the bottom of the hill.

brand.eng_def: a type of product made by a particular company
brand.eg: This isn't my usual brand of deodorant.

brand.eng_def: a particular type of something, or way of doing something
brand.eg: a team that plays a distinctive brand of football

brand.eng_def: a piece of burning wood used to give light
a mark that is burned or frozen into the skin of an animal such as a cow to show who owns it
brand.eg: The brand was still visible on the animal's hide.

brand.eng_def: to say that you think someone is the sort of person that is stated
brand.eg: Because of one minor offence he was branded (as) a common criminal.

brand.eng_def: to mark an animal such as a cow by burning or freezing its skin to show you own it
brand.chi_def: 打烙印於；以烙鐵打（標記）
brand.eg: The cattle were rounded up and branded.

brass.eng_def: a bright yellow metal made from copper and zinc
brass.eg: The door handles were made of brass.

brass.eng_def: the group of brass instruments or players in a band or orchestra
brass.chi_def: （樂隊或管弦樂隊的）銅管樂器部分；銅管樂器手
brass.eg: The brass seems to me to be too loud in this recording.

brass.eng_def: a thin piece of brass on the floor or wall in a church, with a picture or writing cut into it
brass.chi_def: （教堂地上或牆上，刻有雕像或文字的）黃銅紀念牌
brass.eg: The church has several beautiful medieval brasses.

brass.eng_def: complete confidence and lack of fear
brass.chi_def: 高度自信，無所畏懼；厚臉皮
brass.eg: I don't know how she has the brass to do it.

brass.eng_def: (of a musical instrument) made of metal and played by blowing
brass.eg: The trumpet and trombone are brass instruments.

brave.eng_def: showing no fear of dangerous or difficult things
to deal with an unpleasant or difficult situation
brave.eg: Let's brave the snow and go for a walk (= go for a walk even though it is snowing).

brave.eng_def: a young Native American warrior (= fighting man). This word is usually considered offensive.
brave.chi_def: （冒犯性用語）美洲印第安武士

bravery.eg: They were awarded medals for their bravery.

bread.eng_def: a food made from flour, water, and usually yeast, mixed together and baked

breadth.eng_def: the distance from one side to another
breadth.eg: The length of this box is twice its breadth.

breadth.eng_def: the fact of including many different things, features, subjects, or qualities
breadth.eg: The breadth of her knowledge is amazing.

break.eng_def: to (cause something to) separate suddenly or violently into two or more pieces, or to (cause something to) stop working by being damaged
break.chi_def: 破碎，破裂；打破；打斷；損壞，弄壞
break.eg: The dish fell to the floor and broke.

break.eng_def: to destroy or end something, or to come to an end
break.eg: Eventually someone spoke, breaking the silence.

break.eng_def: to do something better than the best known speed, time, number, etc. previously achieved
break.eg: She broke the record for the 5,000 metres.

break.eng_def: to fail to keep a law, rule, or promise
break.eg: He didn't know he was breaking the law (= doing something illegal).

break.eng_def: to (cause something to) divide into two or more parts or groups
break.eg: These enzymes break down food in the stomach (= cause food to separate into smaller pieces).

break.eng_def: to interrupt or to stop something for a short period
break.eg: We usually break for lunch at 12.30.

break.eng_def: to go somewhere or do something by force
break.eg: He threatened to break the door down (= enter using force).

break.eng_def: to lose your confidence, determination, or ability to control yourself, or to make someone do this
break.chi_def: （使）（自控能力、信心、意志等）崩潰
break.eg: He thought she would break under the strain.

break.eng_def: to become known or to make something become known
break.eg: When the scandal broke (= came to the public's attention), the CEO resigned immediately.

break.eng_def: (of waves) to reach and move over the beach, hit a cliff or wall, etc.
break.eg: A huge wave broke on/against the shore/over the boat.

break.eng_def: (of the weather) to change suddenly and usually become worse
break.eg: The forecast is for the hot weather to break today.

break.eng_def: (of a storm) to start suddenly
break.eg: We arrived just as a storm was breaking.

break.eng_def: When dawn or day breaks, the sun starts to appear in the sky early in the morning.
break.eg: Dawn broke over the city.

break.eng_def: When a boy's voice breaks it begins to sound like a man's.
break.eg: His voice broke when he was 13.

break.eng_def: If someone's voice breaks, it changes because of strong emotions.
break.eg: Her voice was breaking with emotion as she pleaded for her child's return.

break.eng_def: (in tennis) to win a game in which another player is serving (= hitting the ball first)
break.eg: Nadal broke Cilic's serve in the second set.

break.eng_def: If a football team breaks, it gets the ball in its own half and attacks quickly into the opposing team's half.
break.eg: Blues broke quickly, catching Wolves on the back foot.

break.eng_def: an interruption
break.eg: Finally there was a break in the rain and we went out.

break.eng_def: the short period of advertisements between television programmes
break.eg: I'll make us a cup of tea in the next break.

break.eng_def: a short period of rest, when food or drink is sometimes eaten
break.chi_def: 休息；（用茶點的）休息時間
break.eg: a coffee break

break.eng_def: the regular time in the middle of the morning or afternoon, for school students to talk or play, and sometimes have food or drink
break.eg: We were talking about it at break.

break.eng_def: a time away from work or your regular activity, or a holiday
break.chi_def: （中斷工作或日常活動的）休息時間；假期
break.eg: Take a couple of weeks off - you need a break.

break.eng_def: to allow someone some time away from their work or regular activities
break.chi_def: 給…一些休息時間；讓…有機會擱下日常的活動或工作
break.eg: I babysit every Friday to give her a break.

break.eng_def: to stop criticizing or annoying someone, or behaving in an unpleasant way
break.eg: Give her a break - she's only a child and she didn't mean any harm.

break.eng_def: an opportunity for improving a situation, especially one that happens unexpectedly
break.eg: Her big break came when she was offered a role in a Spielberg movie.

break.eng_def: a place where something has broken
break.eg: There's a break in the pipe.

break.eng_def: the end of a relationship, connection, or way of doing something
break.eg: Their decision to not name their daughter Jane was a break with family tradition.

break.eng_def: to stop having a close relationship with someone, especially stop living with them , or to change a course of action that you have had for a long time
break.chi_def: 與…結束關係（尤指不再住在一起）；改變（一貫的行為）
break.eg: You've been in your job for years - it's time you made a break.

break.eng_def: in tennis, a game won by the player who was not serving (= hitting the ball first)
break.eg: Murray must get another break (of serve) to win.

break.eng_def: in snooker and billiards, the number of points that a player gets during one turn at hitting the balls
break.chi_def: （桌球和撞球中的）一桿得分，一次連續得分

break.eng_def: in football, an occasion when a defending team gains possession of the ball in its own half and attacks quickly into the opposing team's half
to escape from/towards somewhere or something, often by force
break.eg: A group of prisoners made a break from the jail a few years back.

break.eng_def: the time when the sun rises in the morning
break.eg: We set out at break of day.

breakdown.eng_def: a failure to work or be successful
breakdown.eg: I had a breakdown (= my car stopped working) in the middle of the road.

breakdown.eng_def: a division of something into smaller parts
breakdown.eg: We asked for a breakdown of the accident figures into day time and night time.

breakfast.eng_def: a meal eaten in the morning as the first meal of the day
breakfast.eg: What do you want for breakfast?

breakthrough.eng_def: an important discovery or event that helps to improve a situation or provide an answer to a problem
breakthrough.eg: Scientists are hoping for a breakthrough in the search for a cure for cancer.

breast.eng_def: either of the two soft, rounded parts of a woman's chest that produce milk after she has a baby
breast.eg: When a woman becomes pregnant her breasts tend to grow larger.

breast.eng_def: the front part of a bird's body
breast.eg: A robin is easy to identify because of its red breast.

breast.eng_def: the meat from the front part of the body of a bird or other animal
breast.eg: I had a cold chicken breast and a salad for lunch.

breast.eng_def: the part of a piece of clothing that covers a person's chest
breast.eg: He put a silk hanky in his breast pocket (= a pocket on the top front part of a shirt or coat).

breast.eng_def: the centre of a person's feelings
breast.eg: A feeling of love surged in his breast.

breath.eng_def: the air that goes into and out of your lungs
to pause or rest for a short time until you can breathe comfortably or regularly again
breath.chi_def: 停下來讓呼吸平緩下來
breath.eg: I had to stop running to catch my breath.
Without pausing to draw breath she told me everything.

breath.eng_def: to pause for a short time between doing one thing and the next
breath.eg: Give me a minute to draw breath, won't you?

breath.eng_def: to keep air in your lungs and not release it so that you need more
breath.eg: How long can you hold your breath under water?

breath.eng_def: to wait for something to happen, often feeling anxious
breath.eg: Fans held their breath waiting for the final whistle.

breath.eng_def: a single action of breathing air into your lungs
to breathe air into your lungs (as a single action)
breath.eg: The doctor told me to take a deep breath (= breathe in a lot of air).
There wasn't a breath of air in the room.

breath.eng_def: a short period of time spent outside
breath.chi_def: 在外面稍微呆一會兒；透氣
breath.eg: I'm just going out for a breath of (fresh) air - I won't be long.

breathe.eng_def: to move air into and out of the lungs
breathe.eg: It's so airless in here - I can hardly breathe.

breathe.eng_def: If you allow wine to breathe, you open the bottle for a short time before you drink from it, in order to improve the wine's flavour.

breed.eng_def: to keep animals for the purpose of producing young animals in a controlled way
breed.eg: Terriers are bred for their fighting instincts.

breed.eng_def: (of animals) to have sex and produce young animals
breed.eg: The blackbird, like most birds, breeds in the spring.

breed.eng_def: to cause something to happen, usually something bad
a particular type of animal or plant

breed.eg: Arletty was that rare breed of actress - beautiful, sexy and funny.

breeze.eng_def: something that is easy to achieve, often unexpectedly
breeze.chi_def: （常指出乎意料的）輕而易舉的事
breeze.eg: You won't have any problems with the entrance test - it's an absolute breeze.

breeze.eng_def: to walk somewhere quickly and confidently, without worry or embarrassment
breeze.chi_def: 飄然而行；輕盈而自信地走
breeze.eg: She just breezed in as if she'd only been away a day instead of a year.

breeze.eng_def: to easily complete or win something
breeze.eg: She breezed through the song as though she'd been singing it for years.

brew.eng_def: If you brew tea or coffee, you add boiling water to it to make a hot drink, and if it brews, it gradually develops flavour in the container in which it was made.
brew.chi_def: 泡（茶）；煮（咖啡）；（茶）沖泡；（咖啡）煮
brew.eg: He brewed us some coffee./He brewed some coffee for us.

brew.eng_def: If an unpleasant situation or a storm is brewing, you feel that it is about to happen.
brew.chi_def: （壞事或暴風雨）即將來臨，醖釀
brew.eg: It was too quiet - I felt that trouble was brewing.

brew.eng_def: a type of beer, especially one made in a particular place or at a particular time
brew.chi_def: （尤指某地或某個時間釀造的）啤酒

brew.eng_def: a drink of tea or a drink of beer

brew.eg: They gave her a strange brew to drink.

bribe.eng_def: to try to make someone do something for you by giving them money, presents, or something else that they want
bribe.eg: He bribed immigration officials and entered the country illegally.

bribe.eng_def: money or a present that you give to someone so that they will do something for you, usually something dishonest
bribe.eg: He was accused of accepting/taking bribes from wealthy businessmen.

brick.eng_def: a rectangular block of hard material used for building walls and houses
brick.eg: The chimney was made of bricks.

brick.eng_def: a very helpful and kind person who can be trusted
brick.eg: Thanks for bringing all that food along to the party, Tony. You're a brick!

bride.eng_def: a woman who is about to get married or has just got married
bride.chi_def: 新娘；即將（或剛）結婚的女子
bride.eg: He returned from New York with his lovely new bride.

bridegroom.eng_def: a man who is about to get married or has just got married
bridegroom.chi_def: 新郎；即將（或剛）結婚的男子
bridegroom.eg: The bridegroom was late for the ceremony.

bridge.eng_def: a structure that is built over a river, road, or railway to allow people and vehicles to cross from one side to the other
something that makes it easier to make a change from one situation to another
bridge.eg: Part-time work can provide a bridge between staying at home and working full-time.

bridge.eng_def: the raised part of a ship on which the captain and other officers stand and from where they control the movement of the ship
the top part of the nose, between the eyes, or (on a pair of glasses) the piece that is supported by the top part of the nose
bridge.eg: The blow caught him right on the bridge of his nose.

bridge.eng_def: a card game for four players who play in pairs
a piece of material that contains one or more artificial teeth and is kept in place by being fastened to the natural teeth
bridge.chi_def: 齒橋（裝於真牙上以固定假牙的架子）

bridge.eng_def: a small piece of wood over which the strings are stretched on a musical instrument such as a guitar or violin
to make the difference or division between two things smaller or less severe
bridge.eg: We must bridge the gap between employees and management.

bridge.eng_def: to build a bridge over or across something
bridge.eg: The river had been bridged at its narrowest point.

brief.eng_def: lasting only a short time or containing few words
brief.eg: His acceptance speech was mercifully brief.

brief.eng_def: used to express how quickly time goes past
brief.eg: For a few brief weeks we were very happy.
She was wearing a fairly brief skirt, as I recall.

brief.eng_def: to give someone detailed instructions or information
brief.eg: We had already been briefed about/on what the job would entail.

brief.eng_def: to make information about someone or something public, with the intention of criticizing/praising him, her, or it
brief.chi_def: 透過非正式背景說明​​活動來否定/支持（人或事件），吹風否定/支持（人或事件）
brief.eg: On several occasions government officials briefed against their own ministers.

brief.eng_def: If something is said in brief, it is said in a very short form, with very few details.
brief.eg: "So you didn't enjoy the party much." "In brief, no."

brief.eng_def: a piece of underwear worn by men or women, covering the area between the waist and the tops of the legs
a set of instructions or information
brief.eg: It was my brief to make sure that the facts were set down accurately.

brief.eng_def: a document or set of documents containing the details about a court case
a lawyer who will speak for someone in a court of law
brief.eg: My brief advised me to plead guilty.

briefcase.eng_def: a flat rectangular bag, used especially for carrying business documents

bright.eg: They were bright children, always asking questions.

bright.eng_def: full of hope for success or happiness
bright.eg: You're very bright and cheerful this morning.

bright.eng_def: A car's brights are its headlights (= the powerful lights at the front) when they are brightest and aimed straight ahead.

brilliant.chi_def: 頗有才氣的，聰穎的；技藝高超的
brilliant.eg: Her mother was a brilliant scientist.

brilliant.eng_def: full of light, shining, or bright in colour
brilliant.chi_def: 光明的，明亮的；（顔色）鮮艶的
brilliant.eg: The sky was a brilliant, cloudless blue.
"Did you like the film?" "I thought it was brilliant."

bring.eng_def: to take or carry someone or something to a place or a person, or in the direction of the person speaking
bring.eg: "Shall I bring anything to the party?" "Oh, just a bottle."

bring.eng_def: to cause, result in, or produce a state or condition
bring.eg: She's brought us so much happiness over the years.

bring.eng_def: to cause someone to come to a particular place or thing
bring.chi_def: 把…引到（某一話題），把某人帶到（某一地點）
bring.eg: This subject brings me to the second part of the discussion.

bring.eng_def: to make or begin as part of an official legal process
bring.eg: He was arrested for fighting, but the police have decided not to bring charges.

brink.eng_def: the point where a new or different situation is about to begin
brink.eg: Extreme stress had driven him to the brink of a nervous breakdown.

brink.eng_def: the edge of a cliff or other high area
brink.eg: She was standing right on the brink of the gorge.

broad.eg: We walked down a broad avenue lined with trees.

broad.eng_def: If something is a particular distance broad, it measures this distance from side to side.
broad.eg: This river is over 500 metres broad at its widest point.

broad.eng_def: including a wide range of things; general
broad.eg: The politician gave a broad outline of his proposals.

broad.eng_def: If someone has a broad accent (= way of speaking), it is strong and noticeable, showing where they come from.
broad.eg: He spoke with a broad Australian accent.

broad.eng_def: a hint (= when you tell someone something without saying it directly) that is easy to understand

broadcast.eng_def: to send out a programme on television or radio
broadcast.chi_def: 廣播（電視或無線電節目）；播送
broadcast.eg: Radio Caroline used to broadcast from a boat in the North Sea.

broadcast.eng_def: A broadcast station is a television station sent out from the ground rather than using satellites.

broaden.eng_def: to become wider, or to cause something to become wider
broaden.eg: The track broadens and becomes a road at this point.

broaden.eng_def: to increase the range of something
broaden.eg: They've introduced all sorts of new elements to that programme in order to broaden its appeal.

broaden.eng_def: to make someone understand more and know more about different subjects, ideas, places, etc.
broaden.eg: They say that travel broadens the mind.

brochure.eng_def: a type of small magazine that contains pictures and information on a product or a company
brochure.chi_def: 小冊子；資料（或廣告）手冊

broil.eng_def: to cook something under a very hot surface in a cooker
broil.eg: I'll broil the bacon rather than fry it.

broke.eg: I can't afford to go on holiday this year - I'm (flat) broke.

bronze.eng_def: a brown metal made of copper and tin
bronze.eg: The church bells are made of bronze.

bronze.eng_def: a dark orange-brown colour, like the metal bronze
a statue (= a large artistic object) made of bronze
a small, round piece of bronze given to a person who finishes third in a competition
bronze.eg: He got a bronze in the high jump.

bronze.eng_def: being dark orange-brown in colour, like the metal bronze

brooch.eng_def: a small piece of jewellery with a pin at the back that is fastened to a woman's clothes
brooch.eg: She wore a small silver brooch.

brood.eng_def: a group of young birds all born at the same time
brood.eg: The blackbird flew back and forth to its brood.
Ann was at the party with her brood.

brood.eng_def: to think for a long time about things that make you sad, worried, or angry
brood.eg: I wish she wouldn't sit brooding in her room all day.

brook.eg: I could hear the sound of a babbling brook.

brook.eng_def: to not allow or accept something, especially a difference of opinion or intention
brook.chi_def: 不容忍；不接納（尤指異議）
brook.eg: She won't brook any criticism of her work.

broom.eng_def: a brush with a long handle, used for cleaning the floor
a bush with small yellow flowers

broth.eng_def: a thin soup, often with vegetables or rice in it
broth.chi_def: （與蔬菜或米一起烹製的）肉湯

brother.eng_def: a man or boy with the same parents as another person
brother.eg: Do you have any brothers and sisters?

brother.eng_def: a man who is a member of the same group as you or who shares an interest with you or has a similar way of thinking to you
brother.eg: "Let us unite, brothers and fight this unjust law!"

brother.eng_def: sometimes used by a black man to address or refer to another black man
brother.chi_def: （有時用於黑人男性間的稱呼）老弟，老兄

brother.eng_def: used as the title of a man, such as a monk, who belongs to a religious organization
brother.chi_def: （同一宗教組織的）男性教友，修士
brother.eg: Brother Michael and Brother John were deep in conversation.

brotherhood.chi_def: 兄弟會（成員）；同志會（成員）；同業公會（成員）
brotherhood.eg: The various groups eventually fused into a single brotherhood.
The ideal of the brotherhood of man (= where everyone loves each other) is still far from reality.

brow.eng_def: the forehead (= part of the face above the eyes)
brow.eg: She wrinkled her brow as she thought.

brow.eng_def: the top part of a hill or the edge of something high such as a cliff or rock
brow.chi_def: 山頂；懸崖邊緣；峭壁頂端

brown.eng_def: the colour of chocolate or soil
to make food brown by cooking it
brown.eg: Lightly brown the onion before adding the tomatoes.

browse.eng_def: to look through a book or magazine without reading everything, or to walk around a shop looking at several things without intending to buy any of them
browse.eg: I was browsing through fashion magazines to find a new hairstyle.

browse.eng_def: to look at information on the internet
browse.chi_def: 瀏覽（網際網路）；在網路上瀏覽（資訊）

browse.eng_def: (of animals) to feed on grass, leaves, etc. in a relaxed way
browse.eg: Deer were browsing (on grass) under the trees.

browse.eng_def: an act of browsing or period of time spent browsing
browse.chi_def: 隨便看看，瀏覽；隨便看看（或瀏覽）所花的時間
browse.eg: We went for a browse around an antique shop.

bruise.eng_def: an injury or mark where the skin has not been broken but is darker in colour, often as a result of being hit by something
bruise.eg: His arms and back were covered in bruises.

bruise.eng_def: to develop a bruise or to cause someone or something to have a bruise
bruise.eg: How did you bruise your arm?

brunch.eng_def: a meal eaten in the late morning that is a combination of breakfast and lunch
brunch.eg: We always have brunch together on Sunday.

brush.eng_def: an object with short pieces of stiff hair, plastic, or wire attached to a base or handle, used for cleaning, arranging your hair, or painting
brush.eg: I can't find my brush, but I still have my comb.

brush.eng_def: an act of cleaning with a brush
brush.eg: These shoes need a good brush.
He felt the brush of her hand on his.

brush.eng_def: a situation in which you experience something, or almost experience something, especially something unpleasant
brush.eg: Jim had a brush with death (= was nearly killed) on the motorway.

brush.eng_def: small, low bushes or the rough land they grow on
brush.eg: We spotted a jackrabbit hidden in the brush.

brush.eng_def: to touch (something) quickly and lightly or carelessly
brush.eg: Charlotte brushed against him (= touched him quickly and lightly with her arm or body) as she left the room.

brush.eng_def: to move something somewhere using a brush or your hand
brush.eg: Jackie brushed the hair out of her eyes.

brush.eng_def: to clean something or make something smooth with a brush
brush.eg: When did he last brush his teeth, she wondered.

brutal.eng_def: cruel, violent, and completely without feelings

brutal.chi_def: 直截了當的；不顧及他人感受的
brutal.eg: She spoke with brutal honesty - I was too old for the job.

brute.eng_def: a rough and sometimes violent man
brute.eg: Take your hands off me, you brute!

brute.eng_def: an animal, especially a large one
brute.eg: Your dog's an ugly brute, isn't it?
In the end she used brute force to push him out.

bubble.eng_def: a ball of gas that appears in a liquid, or a ball formed of air surrounded by liquid that floats in the air
bubble.eg: As water begins to boil, bubbles rise to the surface.

bubble.eng_def: a temporary period of very successful economic performance in a particular country or sector, often followed by sudden failure

bubble.eg: We could hear the soup bubbling away (= bubbling strongly) in the pot.

buck.eg: Can I borrow a couple of bucks?

buck.eng_def: used in a number of expressions about money, usually expressions referring to a lot of money
buck.chi_def: （用於某些表達方式中）許多錢
buck.eg: He earns megabucks (= a lot of money) working for an American bank.

buck.eng_def: the male of some animals such as deer and rabbits, or (in South Africa) a male or female antelope
buck.chi_def: 雄性動物；雄鹿；公兔；（南美）羚羊

buck.eng_def: (of a horse) to jump into the air and kick out with the back legs

bucket.eng_def: a container with an open top and a handle, often used for carrying liquids
bucket.eg: Armed with a bucket and a mop, I started washing the floor.

buckle.eng_def: a piece of metal at one end of a belt or strap, used to fasten the two ends together
to fasten or be fastened with a buckle
to bend something or become bent, often as a result of force, heat, or weakness
buckle.eg: The intense heat from the fire had caused the factory roof to buckle.

buckle.eng_def: to be defeated by a difficult situation
buckle.eg: But these were difficult times and a lesser man would have buckled under the strain.

bud.eng_def: a small part of a plant, that develops into a flower or leaf

bud.eg: It was springtime and the fruit trees were in bud.

bud.chi_def: （用於稱呼另一男士，尤用於表示不滿時）老兄

bud.eg: The unusually cold winter has caused many plants to bud late this year.

budget.eng_def: a plan to show how much money a person or organization will earn and how much they will need or be able to spend
budget.eg: The firm has drawn up a budget for the coming financial year.

budget.eng_def: the amount of money you have available to spend
to plan how much money you will spend on something
budget.eg: An extra $20 million has been budgeted for schools this year.

budget.eng_def: in the UK, the official statement that the government makes about how much it will collect in taxes and spend on public services in the future

buffalo.eng_def: a large animal of the cattle family, with long, curved horns

buffet.eng_def: a meal where people serve themselves different types of food
buffet.eg: Are you having a sit-down meal or a buffet at the wedding?

buffet.eng_def: a restaurant in a station, where food and drinks can be bought and eaten
(of wind, rain, etc.) to hit something repeatedly and with great force
buffet.eg: The little boat was buffeted mercilessly by the waves.

bug.eng_def: a bacteria or a virus causing an illness that is usually not serious
bug.eg: I had a tummy/stomach bug last week.

bug.eng_def: a mistake or problem in a computer program
bug.chi_def: （電腦程式中出現的）缺陷，漏洞
bug.eg: A bug caused the company's computer system to crash.

bug.eng_def: a very small device fixed on to a phone or hidden in a room, that allows you to listen to what people are saying without them knowing
a very strong enthusiasm for something
bug.eg: He's been bitten by the sailing bug.
He's been bugging me all morning.

bug.eng_def: to place or hide a listening device inside something
bug.eg: She suspected that her phone had been bugged.

build.eng_def: to make something by putting bricks or other materials together
build.eg: They're building new houses by the river.

build.eng_def: to create and develop something over a long period of time
build.eg: We want to build a better future for our children.

build.eng_def: the size and shape of a person's body
build.eg: She was of slim build with short, dark hair.

building.eng_def: a structure with walls and a roof, such as a house or factory
building.eg: The once-empty site was now covered with buildings.

building.eng_def: the process or business of making structures such as houses or factories

bulb.eng_def: a round root of some plants from which the plant grows

bulge.eng_def: to stick out in a round shape
bulge.eg: Her bags were bulging with shopping.

bulge.eng_def: a curved shape sticking out from the surface of something
bulge.eg: I wondered what the bulge in her coat pocket was.

bulge.eng_def: a sudden increase that soon returns to the usual level
bulge.eg: There was a bulge in spending in the early part of the year.

bulk.eng_def: something or someone that is very large
bulk.eg: She eased her large bulk out of the chair.
It was a document of surprising bulk.
The office buys paper in bulk to keep down costs.
In fact, the bulk of the book is taken up with criticizing other works.

bulky.eng_def: too big and taking up too much space

bull.eng_def: a male cow, or the male of particular animals such as the elephant or the whale
bull.eg: They did not see the sign by the gate saying "Beware of the bull".

bull.eng_def: a person who buys shares in companies hoping the price will rise, so that they can be sold later at a profit
bull.chi_def: （預期證券價格上漲的）買空者，多頭

bull.eng_def: complete nonsense or something that is not true
bull.eg: Don't give me that bull about not knowing the time.

bullet.eng_def: a small, metal object that is shot from a gun
bullet.eg: A bullet had lodged in the boy's leg.

bullet.chi_def: 項目符號（通常為小黑圓點）（同 bullet point）

bulletin.eng_def: a short news programme on television or radio, often about something that has just happened, or a short newspaper printed by an organization
bulletin.chi_def: （電視或電臺的）新聞快報；（機構的）簡報

bully.eng_def: someone who hurts or frightens someone who is smaller or less powerful, often forcing them to do something that they do not want to do
bully.chi_def: 恃強淩弱者，以大欺小者

bully.eng_def: to hurt or frighten someone who is smaller or less powerful than you, often forcing that person to do something they do not want to do
bully.eg: Our survey indicates that one in four children is bullied at school.

bump.eg: She bumped into his tray, knocking the food onto his lap.

bump.eng_def: to hurt part of your body by hitting it against something hard
bump.eg: I bumped my head on the shelf as I stood up.

bump.eng_def: to travel, usually in a vehicle, in an uncomfortable way because the surface you are moving over is rough
bump.eg: We bumped along the dirt road in our car, holding on to our seats.

bump.eng_def: to remove someone from a particular position, sometimes to a different one
bump.eg: He had been playing badly and was bumped from the team.

bump.eng_def: a round, raised area on a surface or on the body
bump.eg: Her bicycle hit a bump in the road and threw her off.

bump.eng_def: the sound of something falling to the ground
bump.eg: We heard a bump from the next room.

bump.eng_def: an accident involving a car, especially one that is not serious
bump.eg: A van drove into their car but luckily it was just a bump.
There had been a bump in the number of students with learning disorders.

bun.eng_def: a small, sweet, usually round cake
a small, round piece of bread, especially one that is cut horizontally and holds a burger
bun.chi_def: （水平切開的）小圓麵包；（尤指）漢堡坯

bun.eng_def: a woman's hairstyle where the hair is brought together into a round shape at the back of the head
bun.eg: She wore her hair in a bun.

bun.eng_def: a buttock (= one side of a person's bottom)

bunch.eng_def: a number of things of the same type fastened together or in a close group
the best person or thing from a group of similar people or things
bunch.chi_def: 出類拔萃的人（或物）；精英；精品
bunch.eg: Send in your poems and we'll publish the best of the bunch.

bunch.eng_def: If a girl has her hair in bunches, it is tied together in two parts with one at each side of her head.
bunch.eg: As a little girl she wore her hair in bunches.

bundle.eng_def: a number of things that have been fastened or are held together
to push or put someone or something somewhere quickly and roughly
bundle.chi_def: 推搡；匆匆送走；亂堆；亂塞
bundle.eg: He bundled his clothes into the washing machine.

bundle.eng_def: to include an extra computer program or other product with something that you sell
bundle.chi_def: （電腦軟體等的）捆綁銷售；搭售
bundle.eg: The system came bundled with a word processor, spreadsheet, and graphics program.

bundle.eng_def: the act of selling several products or services together

burden.eng_def: a heavy load that you carry
burden.eg: The little donkey struggled under its heavy burden.

burden.eng_def: something difficult or unpleasant that you have to deal with or worry about
to trouble someone with something difficult or unpleasant
burden.eg: I don't want to burden you with my problems.

bureau.eng_def: an organization or a business that collects or provides information
bureau.chi_def: （搜集或提供資訊的）辦事處，辦公室，機構
bureau.eg: Her disappearance was reported to the police department's Missing Persons Bureau.

bureau.eng_def: a piece of furniture with a lid that opens to form a writing surface

bureau.chi_def: 五鬥櫥；（有抽屜的）衣櫃，衣櫥

bureaucracy.eng_def: a system for controlling or managing a country, company, or organization that is operated by a large number of officials employed to follow rules carefully
bureaucracy.chi_def: 官僚作風；官僚主義；官僚體制
bureaucracy.eg: I had to deal with the university's bureaucracy when I was applying for financial aid.

burger.eng_def: meat or other food pressed into a round, flat shape and fried
burger.chi_def: 漢堡包；（漢堡式的）夾心餅

burglar.eng_def: a person who illegally enters buildings and steals things

burial.eng_def: the act of putting a dead body into the ground, or the ceremony connected with this
burial.eg: We went back to Ireland for my uncle's burial.

burn.eng_def: to be hurt, damaged, or destroyed by fire or extreme heat, or to cause this to happen
burn.chi_def: （把…）燒壞；（使）燒傷；（使）燒毀；（使）曬傷；（使）燙傷
burn.eg: He was badly burned in the blaze.

burn.eng_def: to cause emotional pain or damage to someone
to kill someone by tying the person to a post and burning them
to completely destroy a building by fire
burn.eg: The building was burned to the ground ten years ago.

burn.eng_def: to be on fire, or to produce flames
burn.eg: The wood was wet and would not burn.
I saw a light burning in her window.

burn.eng_def: If your face burns, it feels very hot.
to want to do something very much
burn.eg: She was burning to tell us her news.

burn.eng_def: to copy information, recorded music, images, etc. onto a CD
burn.chi_def: 把（資料、音樂、圖片等）複製（到光碟上）；刻錄；燒錄
burn.eg: Burn your favourite songs or your important files onto CDs.

burn.eng_def: a place where fire or heat has hurt or damaged something
burn.chi_def: 燒傷（的痕跡）；燙傷（的痕跡）
burn.eg: One rescue worker caught in the explosion sustained severe burns.

burst.eng_def: to break open or apart suddenly, or to make something do this
burst.eg: I hate it when balloons burst.

burst.eng_def: to feel a strong emotion, or strong wish to do something
burst.eg: I knew they were bursting with curiosity but I said nothing.

burst.eng_def: to suddenly burn strongly, producing a lot of flames
burst.eg: Smoke started pouring out from underneath, then the truck burst into flames.

burst.eng_def: the act of breaking open so that what is inside comes out
burst.eg: a burst in the water pipe

burst.eng_def: a sudden increase in something, especially for a short period

bury.eng_def: to put a dead body into the ground
bury.eg: His father is buried in the cemetery on the hill.

bury.eng_def: to put something into a hole in the ground and cover it
bury.eg: The dog trotted off to bury its bone.

bury.eng_def: to cover something or someone completely with a large quantity of something
bury.eg: If an avalanche strikes, skiers can be buried alive by snow.

bury.eng_def: to put something in a place where it is difficult or impossible to find or see
bury.eg: I found the article buried (away) in the business section of the newspaper.

bury.eng_def: to intentionally forget an unpleasant experience
bury.eg: He'd had to bury his pain over the years.

bury.eng_def: If someone says they buried someone, usually a close relation, they mean that the person died.
bury.eg: She buried both her parents last year.

bus.eng_def: a large vehicle in which people are driven from one place to another
bus.eg: You should take the bus/go by bus (= travel by bus) if you want to see the sights.

bus.eng_def: a set of wires in a computer along which information can be sent to and from other parts of the computer
bus.chi_def: （電腦中的）匯流排（其不同輸出線路向電腦各零件傳送資料）

bus.eng_def: to take people somewhere by bus
bus.eg: Demonstrators were bussed in from all parts of the state to attend the protest rally.

bus.eng_def: to take children by bus to school in another area every day

bush.eng_def: a plant with many small branches growing either directly from the ground or from a hard stem, giving the plant a rounded shape
(especially in Australia and Africa) an area of land covered with bushes and trees that has never been used for growing crops and where there are very few people
bush.chi_def: （尤指澳大利亞和非洲長滿灌木叢和樹的）荒野，叢林地

bush.eg: The baby was born with a surprising bush of black hair.

bush.eng_def: someone's pubic hair, especially a woman's

business.eng_def: the activity of buying and selling goods and services
a particular company that buys and sells goods and services
business.eg: The two brothers established/set up/started up a clothes retailing business.

business.eng_def: work that you do to earn money
the amount of work done or the number of goods or services sold by a company or organization
business.eg: Business is good/brisk/booming/flourishing (= I'm selling a lot).

business.eng_def: a situation or activity, often one that you are giving your opinion about
business.chi_def: 狀況；事，事情；事務；重要事件
business.eg: Arranging a trip abroad is a time-consuming business.

business.eng_def: the things that you do or the matters that relate only to you
business.eg: I started on the business of filling out the form.

busy.eng_def: If you are busy, you are working hard, or giving your attention to a particular thing.
busy.eg: Mum was busy in the kitchen.

busy.eng_def: A busy place is full of activity or people.
In a busy period, you have a lot of things to do.
busy.eg: I have a busy week ahead of me.

busy.eng_def: If a phone line is busy, someone is using it.
busy.eg: I tried calling you but the line was busy.

busy.eng_def: having too much decoration or too many colours
busy.chi_def: 繁瑣的，雜亂的；使人眼花繚亂的
busy.eg: The jacket was a bit too busy for my tastes - I'd prefer something plainer.

busy.eng_def: to make the time pass by doing something
busy.eg: I busied myself with tidying up my desk.

but.eng_def: used to introduce an added statement, usually something that is different from what you have said before
but.eg: She's very hard-working but not very imaginative.
Eventually, all but one of them promised to come to his birthday party.

but.eng_def: used to give force to a statement
but.eg: Everyone, but everyone, will be there.

but.eng_def: used to emphasize that something will happen even if the person you are talking to does not want it to
but.chi_def: 沒有「但是」可言；沒有商量的餘地
but.eg: We're going to visit your aunt tomorrow and there'll be no buts about it.

butcher.eng_def: a person who sells meat in a shop
someone who murders a lot of people, especially in a cruel way
to cut an animal into pieces of meat
to kill someone in a very violent way

butter.eng_def: a pale yellow solid food containing a lot of fat that is made from cream and is spread on bread or used in cooking
butter.eg: We were served scones with butter and jam.

butterfly.eng_def: a type of insect with large, often brightly coloured wings
a person who is not responsible or serious, and who is likely to change activities easily or only be interested in pleasure
butterfly.chi_def: 輕浮多變的人；追求享樂的人

butterfly.eng_def: the small metal part put on the back of a stud (= piece of jewellery worn in the ear) that keeps it in place
a way of swimming on your front by kicking with your legs while raising your arms together out of the water and then bringing them down in front of you

button.eng_def: a small, usually circular object used to fasten something, for example a shirt or coat
button.eg: I did up/undid (= fastened/unfastened) the buttons on my blouse.

button.eng_def: a small, sometimes circular object that you press to operate a device or a machine, or an area on a computer screen that looks and acts like one of these
button.eg: He inserted the disk and pressed the "play" button.

button.eng_def: to fasten something, usually a piece of clothing, using buttons
button.eg: Button (up) your coat, it's cold outside.

buy.eng_def: to get something by paying money for it
buy.eg: Eventually she had saved enough money to buy a small car.

buy.eng_def: to pay someone or do something for someone, so that that person does not tell anyone something that they know about and that you want to remain secret
buy.eg: What will we have to do to buy her silence?

buy.eng_def: to believe that something is true
buy.eg: She'll never buy that story about you getting lost!

buy.eng_def: to be worth/not be worth the price
buy.eg: This jacket is a really good buy, at £200.

buzz.eng_def: to make a continuous, low sound such as the one a bee makes
to press a buzzer in order to get someone's attention
buzz.eg: I buzzed him but there was no answer.

buzz.eng_def: to be busy and full of energy
If your head/mind is buzzing, you are thinking about many different things at the same time.
If an aircraft buzzes a place or people, it flies over it or them very low and fast.
to cut someone's hair very short using a special machine
buzz.chi_def: （用特殊的機器）將頭髮剪得非常短

buzz.eg: I heard a buzz and then saw the plane in the distance.

buzz.eng_def: a feeling of excitement, energy, and pleasure
buzz.eg: I love riding fast - it gives me a real buzz.

by.eng_def: used to show the person or thing that does something
by.chi_def: （用於表示動作的施動者）被，由
by.eg: The motorcycle was driven by a tiny bald man.

by.eng_def: used to show how something is done
by.eg: They travelled across Europe by train/car.

by.eng_def: near or at the side of
by.eg: A small child stood sullenly by her side.

by.eng_def: not later than; at or before
by.eg: She had promised to be back by five o'clock.

by.eng_def: used to show measurements or amounts
by.eg: Our office floor space measured twelve metres by ten (= was twelve metres in one direction and ten in the other).

by.eng_def: used to say that something increases or changes with every minute, hour, day, etc. that passes
by.chi_def: 隨著每分鐘（每小時，每天）的過去
by.eg: The death toll from the hurricane was climbing minute by minute/by the minute.

by.eng_def: describing or showing what happens every minute, hour, etc.
by.chi_def: 每分鐘（每小時等）的（變化）
by.eg: a minute-by-minute timeline of the incident
We travelled by night and rested by day.

by.eng_def: used when describing someone's character, job, etc.
by.eg: She is, by nature, a sunny, positive kind of person.

by.eng_def: If something is all right/fine by someone, they agree that it can happen.
by.eg: "I'd rather go later." "That's fine by me."

by.eng_def: at the side of or (in distance or time) past
by.eg: The policewoman walked by without saying a word.

bye.eng_def: If someone is given a bye, they are allowed to miss out part of a competition and continue to the next stage without having to win anything.
bye.eg: European teams were granted a bye into the third round of the Cup.

byte.eng_def: a unit of computer information, consisting of a group of (usually eight) bits

cab.eng_def: the separate front part of a large vehicle, such as a truck, bus, or train, in which the driver sits
cab.chi_def: （卡車、公共汽車、火車等大型車輛的）駕駛室

cab.eg: It'll save time if we go by cab.

cab.eng_def: in the past, a vehicle pulled by a horse, used as a taxi

cabbage.eng_def: a large, round vegetable with large green, white, or purple leaves that can be eaten cooked or uncooked
a person who has lost all their powers of thought or speech, usually as the result of a serious accident or illness
cabbage.chi_def: （通常由於嚴重的事故或疾病導致喪失思考和語言能力的）植物人

cabin.eng_def: a small, simple house made of wood
a small room where you sleep in a ship
the area where passengers sit in an aircraft
a small separate space for someone to work in, inside a larger office
cabin.chi_def: 大辦公室內隔離的辦公空間

cabinet.eng_def: a small group of the most important people in government, who advise the President or Prime Minister and make important decisions
a piece of furniture with shelves, cupboards, or drawers, used for storing or showing things
cabinet.eg: Valuable pieces of china were on display in a glass-fronted cabinet.

cable.eng_def: a set of wires, covered by plastic, that carries electricity, phone signals, etc.

cable.chi_def: （電視節目或電話訊號的）有線傳輸系統（同 cable televisioin）
cable.eg: The office has gone over to cable.

cable.eng_def: to put cables under the ground in an area so that television or phone signals can be sent along them
cable.eg: Many rural areas have not yet been cabled.

cactus.eng_def: any of many types of desert plant usually with sharp spines and thick stems for storing water

cafeteria.eng_def: a restaurant (often in a factory, a college, or an office building) where people collect food and drink from a serving area and take it to a table themselves after paying for it
cafeteria.chi_def: （常指工廠、大學或辦公大樓內的）自助餐廳，自助食堂

caffeine.eng_def: a chemical, found for example in tea and coffee, that is a stimulant (= something that makes people more active)

café.eng_def: a restaurant where simple and usually quite cheap meals are served
café.chi_def: （一般不供應酒類的）小餐館，小飯館，咖啡館
café.eg: There's a little café on the corner that serves very good coffee.

cage.eng_def: a space surrounded on all sides by bars or wire, in which animals or birds are kept
to put or keep birds or animals in a cage

cake.eng_def: a sweet food made with a mixture of flour, eggs, fat, and sugar
cake.eg: Would you like a piece of/a slice of/some cake?

cake.eng_def: a small flat object made by pressing together a soft substance
to cover something or someone thickly with a substance that then dries out
cake.chi_def: （用會變乾的東西厚厚地）覆蓋；（使）結塊；凝結
cake.eg: The men were caked in layers of filth and grime.

calcium.eng_def: a chemical element that is present in teeth, bones, and chalk

call.eng_def: to give someone or something a name, or to know or address someone by a particular name

call.eng_def: to consider something as belonging to you

camp.eng_def: a place where people stay in tents or other temporary structures

catalogue.eng_def: a book with a list of all the goods that you can buy from a shop

catalogue.eng_def: A catalogue of unwanted events is a series of them.
