certainty.eng_def: the state of being completely confident or having no doubt about something
certainty.eg: I'm unable to answer that question with any certainty.

certainty.eng_def: something that is very likely to happen
certainty.chi_def: 必然的事；很有可能發生的事
certainty.eg: Joan will win - that's a certainty.

certificate.eng_def: an official document that states that the information on it is true
the qualification that you receive when you are successful in an exam
certificate.chi_def: 成績合格證書；畢業證書
certificate.eg: She has a Certificate in Drama Education.

certify.eng_def: to say in a formal or official way, usually in writing, that something is true or correct
certify.eg: I hereby certify (that) the above information is true and accurate.

certify.eng_def: to say officially that someone is mentally ill
certify.eg: As a young man, he had been certified and sent to a hospital for the mentally ill.

chain.eng_def: a set of connected or related things
chain.eg: She has built up a chain of 180 bookshops across the country.

chain.eng_def: (a length of) rings usually made of metal that are connected together and used for fastening, pulling, supporting, or limiting freedom, or as jewellery
chain.eg: The gates were locked with a padlock and a heavy steel chain.
The hostages were kept in chains for 23 hours a day.

chain.eng_def: a fact or situation that limits a person's freedom
chain.eg: At last the country has freed itself from the chains of the authoritarian regime.

chain.eng_def: a situation in which someone selling a house cannot complete the sale because the person who wants to buy it needs to sell their house first
chain.chi_def: 售屋鏈（指賣家無法售出房屋，原因是買家尚未售出自己的房屋）
chain.eg: Some sellers refuse to exchange contracts with buyers who are in a chain.

chain.eng_def: to fasten someone or something using a chain
chain.eg: It's so cruel to keep a pony chained up like that all the time.

chair.eng_def: a seat for one person that has a back, usually four legs, and sometimes two arms

chair.chi_def: （用以處決罪犯的）電椅（the electric chair的非正式說法）

chair.eng_def: (the official position of) a person in charge of a meeting, official group or organization
chair.eg: Who will take the chair at the next meeting?

chair.eng_def: (the position of) the person in charge of a college or university department
chair.eg: He was appointed to the Chair of Physics at Cambridge in the early 20th century.

chair.eng_def: to be the person in charge of a meeting, etc.
chair.eg: Would you like to chair tomorrow's meeting?

chairman.eng_def: a person in charge of a meeting or organization

chairperson.eg: The role of the chairperson in our meetings is clearly defined.

chairwoman.eng_def: a woman in charge of a meeting or organization
chairwoman.chi_def: （會議或組織的）女主持人，女主席

chalk.eng_def: a type of soft white rock
a stick of this rock or a similar substance used for writing or drawing
chalk.eg: He picked up a piece of chalk and wrote the answer on the blackboard.

chalk.eng_def: to write something with a piece of chalk

challenge.eng_def: (the situation of being faced with) something that needs great mental or physical effort in order to be done successfully and therefore tests a person's ability
challenge.eg: Finding a solution to this problem is one of the greatest challenges faced by scientists today.

challenge.eng_def: an invitation to compete or take part, especially in a game or argument
challenge.chi_def: （尤指比賽或辯論）挑戰（書），邀請
challenge.eg: "I bet you can't eat all that food on your plate." "Is that a challenge?"

challenge.eng_def: asking if something is true or legal
challenge.eg: The result of the vote poses a serious challenge to the government's credibility.

challenge.eng_def: an instruction given by a soldier or guard at a border or gate, telling someone to stand still and say their name and reasons for being there
the act of refusing to accept someone as a member of a jury
challenge.chi_def: （對某人出庭擔任陪審員表示的）反對，拒絕
challenge.eg: A challenge to a member of the jury should be made before the trial begins.

challenge.eng_def: to invite someone to compete or take part, especially in a game or argument
challenge.eg: Tina has challenged me to a game of poker

challenge.eng_def: to question if something is true or legal
challenge.eg: Children challenge their parents' authority far more nowadays than they did in the past.

challenge.eng_def: to test someone's ability or determination
to tell someone at a border or gate to stand still and say their name and reasons for being there
to refuse to accept someone as a member of a jury
challenge.chi_def: （對某人出庭擔任陪審員）表示反對，拒絕

chamber.eng_def: a room used for a special or official purpose, or a group of people who form (part of) a parliament
chamber.chi_def: （用於特定用途或官方用途的）房間，室，廳；議院
chamber.eg: Meetings of the council are held in the council chamber.

chamber.eng_def: a judge's private office. A judge may have legal discussions with lawyers in private in his or her chambers.
an office, especially of a person in an important position
If a trial is in chambers, it happens in a court room without the public, newspaper reporters, etc. being there.
chamber.chi_def: 進行（無公眾和記者參加的）不公開審理的

chamber.eng_def: a room in a house, especially a bedroom
a closed space in a machine, plant, or body
chamber.eg: The human heart has four chambers.

champagne.eng_def: an expensive white or pink fizzy (= with bubbles) wine made in the Champagne area of Eastern France, or, more generally, any similar wine. Champagne is often drunk to celebrate something
champagne.eg: We always celebrate our wedding anniversary with a bottle of champagne.

champion.eng_def: someone or something, especially a person or animal, that has beaten all other competitors in a competition
a person who enthusiastically supports, defends, or fights for a person, belief, right, or principle
champion.chi_def: 擁護者；衛士，捍衛者；鬥士
champion.eg: She has long been a champion of prisoners' rights/the disabled/free speech.

champion.eng_def: to support, defend, or fight for a person, belief, right, or principle enthusiastically
champion.eg: He has championed constitutional reform for many years.

champion.chi_def: 優秀的，第一流的，很好的

championship.eng_def: a high-level competition to decide who is the best, especially in a sport
championship.chi_def: （尤指體育比賽的）冠軍賽，錦標賽

championship.eng_def: the position of being a champion
championship.eg: She has held the championship for the past three years.

championship.eng_def: the support someone gives to a person, belief, right, or principle
championship.chi_def: 擁護者；衛士，捍衛者；鬥士

chance.eng_def: an occasion that allows something to be done
chance.eg: I didn't get/have a chance to speak to her.

chance.eng_def: the level of possibility that something will happen
chance.eg: You'd have a better chance/more chance of passing your exams if you worked a bit harder.

chance.eng_def: a possibility that something negative will happen
chance.chi_def: （不好的事情發生的）危險，風險
chance.eg: I'm delivering my work by hand - I'm not taking any chances.

chance.eng_def: the force that causes things to happen without any known cause or reason for doing so
chance.eg: Roulette is a game of chance.

chance.eng_def: used to ask a question or request in a polite way
chance.chi_def: （用於詢問或禮貌地請求）也許，可能
chance.eg: Are you Hungarian, by any chance?
You'd be a fool to chance your life savings on a single investment.

chance.eng_def: to happen or do something by chance
chance.eg: They chanced to be in the restaurant when I arrived.

change.eng_def: to exchange one thing for another thing, especially of a similar type
change.eg: She's just changed jobs.

change.eng_def: to make or become different
change.eg: I almost didn't recognize her - she'd changed so much.

change.eng_def: to take something you have bought back to a shop and exchange it for something else
change.chi_def: （將購買的東西拿回店裡去）換，交換
change.eg: I had to change those trousers I bought for (= take them back to the shop in order to get) a bigger pair.

change.eng_def: to form a new opinion or make a new decision about something that is different from your old one
change.eg: If you change your mind about coming tonight, just give me a call.

change.eng_def: to improve
change.eg: Her attitude has definitely changed for the better since she started this new job.

change.eng_def: to improve the bad parts of your behaviour
change.eg: If he wants to carry on living here, he's going to have to change his ways and learn to be a bit less messy.

change.eng_def: to get off a train, bus, etc. and catch another in order to continue a journey
change.chi_def: 換乘，轉乘（火車、公共汽車等）
change.eg: I had to change (trains) twice to get there.

change.eng_def: to get or give money in exchange for money, either because you want it in smaller units, or because you want the same value in foreign money
change.eg: Could you change a £10 note (for two fives), please?

change.eng_def: to remove one set of clothes and put a different set on yourself or a young child, especially a baby, or to remove dirty sheets from a bed and put clean ones on it
change.eg: You don't need to change - you look great as you are.

change.eng_def: When the wind or the tide (= the rise and fall of the sea) changes, it starts to move in a different direction.
change.eg: The tide is starting to change.

change.eng_def: to put a vehicle into a different gear, usually in order to change the speed at which it is moving
change.eg: to change gear

change.eng_def: the act of becoming different, or the result of something becoming different
change.eg: Let me know if there's any change in the situation.

change.eng_def: something that is pleasant or interesting because it is unusual or new
change.chi_def: （令人愉快或有趣的）改進，改變
change.eg: It's nice to see her smile for a change.

change.eng_def: a new situation
change.eg: She'd been with the same company for too many years and felt she needed a change of scene, so she applied for a job as a stage manager.

change.eng_def: money in the form of coins rather than notes
change.eg: She gave me €5 in change.

change.eng_def: smaller units of money given in exchange for larger units of the same amount
change.eg: Do you have change for a 20-dollar bill?

change.eng_def: the money that is returned to someone who has paid for something that costs less than the amount that they gave
change.eg: I think you've given me the wrong change.

change.eng_def: the action of putting on different clothes
change.eg: She did a quick change before going on TV.

change.eng_def: a set of clothes as well as the ones that you are wearing
change.eg: You'll need a change of clothes if you're staying overnight.

change.eng_def: the action of getting off a train, bus, etc. and catching another in order to continue a journey
change.chi_def: 換乘，轉乘（火車、公共汽車等）
change.eg: I hate journeys where you've got a lot of changes.

changeable.eng_def: Something that is changeable often changes.
changeable.eg: The weather in Britain is notoriously changeable.

channel.eng_def: a passage for water or other liquids to flow along, or a part of a river or other area of water that is deep and wide enough to provide a route for ships to travel along
channel.chi_def: （水或其他液體流通的）管道，管道；航道
channel.eg: There are drainage/irrigation channels all over this flat agricultural land.

channel.eng_def: the area of sea that separates England from France
channel.eg: We're going to have a day-trip across the Channel.

channel.eng_def: a way of communicating with people or getting something done
channel.eg: We must open the channels of communication between the two countries.

channel.eng_def: a way of making a product, information, etc. available
channel.chi_def: （提供產品、資訊等的）管道，方法
channel.eg: The insurer sells its products through a variety of distribution channels, including banks.

channel.eng_def: a route or way out of an airport or port where travellers' bags are examined
channel.chi_def: （機場或港口檢查旅客行李的）通道
channel.eg: If you have nothing to declare, go through the green channel.

channel.eng_def: to direct something into a particular place or situation
channel.eg: Ditches were constructed to channel water away from the buildings.

channel.eng_def: to behave like or copy another person, so that you almost seem to be that other person
channel.eg: The band were dressed in 1960s outfits and seemed to be channelling the Beatles.

chant.eng_def: to repeat or sing a word or phrase continuously
chant.chi_def: 重複地說（或唱）；反覆吟唱；反覆唸誦
chant.eg: The crowd were chanting the team's name.

chant.eng_def: to sing a religious prayer or song to a simple tune
chant.chi_def: 反復地（用簡單的調子）頌唱禱文
chant.eg: We could hear the monks chanting.

chant.eng_def: a word or phrase that is repeated many times
chant.eg: The fans started to sing the familiar football chant, "Here we go, here we go, here we go!"

chaos.eng_def: a state of total confusion with no order
chaos.eg: Snow and ice have caused chaos on the roads.

chapter.eng_def: any of the separate parts into which a book or other piece of text is divided, usually given a number or title
a period that is part of a larger amount of time during which something happens
chapter.eg: The period before the revolution is an interesting chapter in British history.

chapter.eng_def: a local division of a larger organization
chapter.chi_def: （機構組織的）地方分會，地方支部
chapter.eg: The local chapter of the League of Women Voters meets at the library.

character.eng_def: the particular combination of qualities in a person or place that makes them different from others
character.eg: Politeness is traditionally part of the British character.

character.eng_def: qualities that are interesting and unusual
the quality of being determined and able to deal with difficult situations
character.eg: She has such strength of character.

character.eng_def: a person represented in a film, play, or story
character.chi_def: （電影、戲劇或故事中的）人物，角色
character.eg: The film revolves around three main characters.

character.eng_def: a person, especially when you are describing a particular quality that they have
character.eg: She's a curious character - I don't really know what to think of her.

character.eng_def: someone whose behaviour is different from most people's, especially in a way that is interesting or funny
character.chi_def: 與眾不同的人；（尤指）有趣的人，好玩的人
character.eg: Ted's quite a character/a real character - he's 70 now and still riding that motorbike.

character.eng_def: a letter, number, or other mark or sign used in writing or printing, or the space one of these takes
character.chi_def: （書寫或印刷的）字母，字（或數字、標記、符號）；字元
character.eg: a string of characters (= a line of marks)

characteristic.eng_def: a typical or noticeable quality of someone or something
characteristic.eg: Unfortunately a big nose is a family characteristic.

characteristic.eng_def: typical of a person or thing
characteristic.eg: With the hospitality so characteristic of these people, they opened their house to over 50 guests.

characterize.eng_def: Something that characterizes another thing is typical of it.
characterize.eg: Bright colours and bold strokes characterize his early paintings.

characterize.eng_def: to describe something by stating its main qualities
characterize.chi_def: 歸納…的特徵；描述…的特性
characterize.eg: In her essay, she characterizes the whole era as a period of radical change.

charcoal.eng_def: a hard, black substance similar to coal that can be used as fuel or, in the form of sticks, as something to draw with

charge.eng_def: to ask an amount of money for something, especially a service or activity
charge.chi_def: （尤指對某一服務或活動）收費，要價，開價
charge.eg: How much/What do you charge for a haircut and blow-dry?

charge.eng_def: to record an amount that a customer has spent for them to pay at a later time, according to an agreement between a business and the customer
charge.eg: Charge the bill to my account, please.

charge.eng_def: (of the police) to make a formal statement saying that someone is accused of a crime
to publicly accuse someone of doing something bad
charge.eg: The paper charged her with using the company's money for her own purposes.

charge.eng_def: to move forward quickly and violently, especially towards something that has caused difficulty or anger
charge.eg: The bull lowered its horns and charged.

charge.eng_def: to hurry from one place to another
charge.eg: I've been charging about/around all day and I'm exhausted.

charge.eng_def: to put enough explosive into a gun to fire it once
to order someone to do something
charge.eg: He was charged with taking care of the premises.

charge.eng_def: When a judge charges a jury, he or she explains the details of the law to them.
charge.chi_def: （法官）向（陪審團）解釋法律細節

charge.eng_def: to put electricity into an electrical device such as a battery
charge.eg: She drove the car round the block to charge (up) its batteries.

charge.eng_def: the amount of money that you have to pay for something, especially for an activity or service
charge.chi_def: （尤指某一活動或服務的）收費，費用，價格
charge.eg: Is there a charge for children or do they go free?

charge.eng_def: a formal police statement saying that someone is accused of a crime
charge.eg: The 19-year-old will be appearing in court on Thursday where she will face criminal charges.

charge.eng_def: the act of accusing someone of something bad
charge.eg: The president responded angrily to the charge that she had lost touch with her country's people.

charge.eng_def: being the person who has control of or is responsible for someone or something
charge.eg: Who will be in charge of the department when Sophie leaves?

charge.eng_def: responsibility for controlling or caring for something
charge.eg: Her ex-husband has charge of the children during the week and she has them at the weekend.

charge.eng_def: a person, especially a child, who is in your care and who you are responsible for
the amount of explosive to be fired at one time, or the bullet or other explosive object shot from a gun
an attack in which people or animals suddenly run forward
an order to do something
the amount of electricity that an electrical device stores or that a substance carries
If something is on charge, you are putting an amount of electricity into it.
charge.eg: Is it all right to leave/put the battery on charge overnight?

chariot.eng_def: a two-wheeled vehicle that was used in ancient times for racing and fighting and was pulled by a horse or horses
chariot.chi_def: （古時用於比賽或戰爭的）雙輪馬車

charitable.eng_def: giving money, food, or help free to those who are in need because they are ill, poor, or have no home
kind, and not judging other people in a severe way
charitable.eg: Some critics said the show was good in parts - those less charitable said the whole thing was a disaster.

charity.eng_def: a system of giving money, food, or help free to those who are in need because they are ill, poor, or have no home, or any organization that has the purpose of providing money or helping in this way
charity.chi_def: 慈善事業；慈善組織，慈善機構
charity.eg: She does a lot of work for charity.

charity.eng_def: the quality of being kind to people and not judging them in a severe way

charm.eng_def: a quality that makes you like or feel attracted to someone or something
an object or saying that is thought to have magical powers, such as the ability to bring good luck
charm.eg: He keeps a rabbit's paw as a lucky/good luck charm.

charm.eng_def: a small object, especially one made of gold or silver, worn on a chain as jewellery
charm.chi_def: （首飾鏈上的）小飾物（尤指金製或銀製）

charm.eng_def: to attract someone or persuade someone to do something because of your charm
charm.eg: We were charmed by his boyish manner.

chart.eng_def: a drawing that shows information in a simple way, often using lines and curves to show amounts
chart.eg: There is a chart on the classroom wall showing the relative heights of all the children.

chart.eng_def: a detailed map of an area of water
the lists produced each week of the records with the highest sales
to show something on a chart
chart.eg: We need some sort of graph on which we can chart our progress.

chart.eng_def: to watch something with careful attention or to record something in detail
chart.eg: A global study has just been started to chart the effects of climate change.

chart.eng_def: to arrange a plan of action
chart.eg: The local branch of the party is meeting to chart their election campaign.
Their first record didn't even chart.

chase.eng_def: to hurry after someone or something in order to catch him, her, or it
chase.eg: The police car was going so fast, it must have been chasing someone.

chase.eng_def: to hurry or run in various directions
chase.eg: She couldn't study with the children chasing around the house.

chase.eng_def: to try to get something that is difficult to get or achieve
chase.eg: It's depressing how many people there are chasing so few jobs.

chase.eng_def: to try very hard to persuade someone to have a relationship with you
to run after a person or an animal in a threatening way in order to make him, her, or it leave
chase.eg: He used to chase the children away from his apple trees.

chase.eng_def: the act of going after someone or something very quickly in order to catch him, her, or it
chase.eg: a tedious movie with endless car/police chases

chat.eng_def: to talk to someone in a friendly informal way
chat.eg: She spends hours on the phone chatting to her friends.

chat.eng_def: to take part in a discussion that involves sending messages over the internet, by smartphone, etc.
chat.eg: Use the app to chat and send photos free from anywhere in the world.
Why don't you give me a call and we'll have a chat?

chat.eng_def: a discussion that involves sending messages over the internet, by phone, using a messaging service, etc.
chat.chi_def: （在網路上或通過電話）傳簡訊（聊天）
chat.eg: How do I start a group chat?

chatter.eng_def: to talk for a long time about things that are not important
chatter.eg: She spent the morning chattering away to her friends.

chatter.eng_def: If animals chatter, they make quick, repeated noises.
chatter.chi_def: （指動物）嘰嘰喳喳，吱吱叫，咯咯叫
chatter.eg: The gun shot made the monkeys chatter in alarm.

chatter.eng_def: If your teeth chatter, they knock together repeatedly because you are very cold or frightened.
chatter.chi_def: （牙齒因受冷或受驚而）咯咯作響，打顫
chatter.eg: I could hardly talk, my teeth were chattering so much.

chatter.eng_def: conversation about things that are not important
chatter.eg: I can't concentrate with Ann's constant chatter.

chatter.eng_def: the quick, repeated noises that some animals make
chatter.chi_def: （動物的）鳴叫聲，啁啾聲，吱吱的叫聲
chatter.eg: He could hear the chatter of birds in the trees overhead.

chatter.eng_def: communication between people over the internet
chatter.eg: Experts monitor internet chatter for the government.

cheap.eng_def: costing little money or less than is usual or expected
cheap.eg: I got a cheap flight at the last minute.

cheap.eng_def: If a shop or restaurant is cheap, it charges low prices.
cheap.eg: I go to the cheapest hairdresser's in town.
There's a restaurant round the corner that serves cheap and cheerful food.

cheap.eng_def: If you get goods on the cheap, you get them for a low price, often from someone you know who works in the company or business that produces them.
used to describe goods that are both low in quality and low in price
cheap.eg: I bought some cheap wine for cooking with.

cheap.eng_def: costing little and of very bad quality

cheap.eg: He's so cheap he didn't even buy me a card for my birthday.

cheap.eng_def: If you describe the way a person is dressed as cheap, you mean that it is very obvious that they are trying to sexually attract other people.

cheap.eg: I wish you'd stop making cheap jokes about my friends.

cheap.eng_def: for little money or for less than is usual
cheap.eg: I got some shoes cheap in the sale.

cheat.eng_def: to behave in a dishonest way in order to get what you want
cheat.eg: Anyone caught cheating will be immediately disqualified from the exam.

cheat.eng_def: a person who behaves in a dishonest way
cheat.eg: Trouble broke out in the match when one of the players called a member of the other team a cheat.

cheat.eng_def: something dishonest that makes people believe that something is true when it is not
cheat.eg: You can use cocoa powder to make the cake rather than chocolate - it's a bit of a cheat, but nobody notices the difference.

cheat.eng_def: a collection of instructions or special information that someone can use to help them play a computer game more successfully
cheat.chi_def: （玩電腦遊戲時使用的）秘技，作弊碼

check.eng_def: to make certain that something or someone is correct, safe, or suitable by examining it, him, or her quickly
check.eg: You should always check your oil, water, and tyres before taking your car on a long trip.

check.eng_def: to find out about something
check.eg: I called them yesterday to check when they were arriving.

check.eng_def: to stop someone from doing or saying something, or to prevent something from increasing or continuing
check.eg: They have begun to vaccinate children in an attempt to check the spread of the disease.

check.eng_def: to give your bags to airport employees to be put on a plane for you, rather than carrying them on and off the plane yourself
check.eg: I got my boarding pass and checked my suitcase.

check.eng_def: to leave something with someone at a particular place, so that they can take care of it for a short time
check.eg: It was hot so we checked our coats before going round the gallery.

check.eng_def: If information checks, it agrees with other information.
check.eg: Her statement checks with most of the eye-witness reports.

check.eng_def: to mark something with a check
check.eg: Check (off) each item on the list as you complete it.

check.eng_def: in the game of chess, to put the other player's king under direct attack, so that he or she is forced to defend against the attack in the next move
in some sports such as ice hockey, to try to make another player lose the ball or puck, for example, by pushing them
US spelling of  cheque UK
an examination of something in order to make certain that it is correct or the way it should be
check.eg: The soldiers gave their equipment a final check before setting off.

check.eng_def: a pattern of squares formed by lines of different colours crossing each other
check.eg: a shirt with a pattern of blue and yellow checks

check.eng_def: a  bill  in a restaurant, etc.
check.eg: Can I have the check, please?

check.eng_def: to limit something
check.eg: We need to find ways of keeping our expenditure in check.

check.eng_def: rules intended to prevent one person or group from having too much power within an organization
check.chi_def: （組織內部的）制約與平衡，制衡原則
check.eg: A system of checks and balances exists to ensure that our government is truly democratic.

check.eng_def: a mark (✓) that shows that something is correct or has been done
check.eg: Put a check by/against the names of the people who have accepted the invitation.

check.eng_def: in chess, the act of directly attacking the other player's king
check.chi_def: （下西洋棋時）攻王，將（對方的）軍
check.eg: I think I should have given check (= attacked my opponent's king) at move 23 instead of trying to find a safer square for the rook.

check.eng_def: If your king is in check in chess, it is being directly attacked by the other player.
check.eg: Your king is in check from my knight.

check.eng_def: in some sports such as ice hockey, a defensive move (= trying to prevent scoring) in which a player tries to make another player lose the ball or puck, for example, by pushing them
used to say yes to someone who is making certain that all the things on a list have been dealt with or included
check.chi_def: （用於確認所列事項已完成）是的，已照辦

check.eng_def: something you say in chess, if you directly attack the other player's king

check-in.eng_def: the area at an airport where you show your ticket so that you can be told where you will be sitting
check-in.eg: A representative from the tour company will meet you at the check-in.

check-in.eng_def: the act of showing your ticket at an airport so that you can be told where you will be sitting
check-in.eg: After check-in, please proceed to gate 26.

checkup.eng_def: a medical examination to test your general state of health
checkup.eg: She goes to her doctor for regular check-ups.

cheek.eng_def: the soft part of your face that is below your eye and between your mouth and ear
cheek.eg: The tears ran down her cheeks.

cheek.eng_def: behaviour or talk that is rude and shows no respect
cheek.eg: He told me off for being late when he arrived half an hour after me. What a cheek!

cheek.eng_def: either of the two halves of your bottom

cheek.eg: He's always getting into trouble for cheeking his teachers.

cheer.eng_def: to give a loud shout of approval or encouragement
cheer.eg: Everyone cheered as the winners received their medals.

cheer.eng_def: a loud shout of approval or encouragement
cheer.eg: Her speech was received with cheers and a standing ovation.
The victory in the by-election has brought great cheer to the Liberal Democrats.

cheerful.chi_def: 高興的，快樂的；興高采烈的

cheerful.eng_def: used to describe a place or thing that is bright and pleasant and makes you feel positive and happy
cheerful.chi_def: 令人高興的，令人愉快的；賞心悅目的
cheerful.eg: The doctor's waiting room was bright and cheerful with yellow walls and curtains.

cheese.eng_def: a food made from milk, that can be either firm or soft and is usually yellow or white in colour
cheese.eg: Would you like a slice/piece of cheese with your bread?

chef.eng_def: a skilled and trained cook who works in a hotel or restaurant, especially the most important cook
chef.chi_def: （飯店或餐館的）廚師；（尤指）廚師長，大廚，主廚
chef.eg: He is one of the top chefs in Britain.

chemical.eng_def: any basic substance that is used in or produced by a reaction involving changes to atoms or molecules
chemical.eg: The government has pledged to reduce the amount of chemicals used in food production.
The chemical industry produces such things as petrochemicals, drugs, and rubber.

chemist.eng_def: a person who studies chemistry, or a scientist who works with chemicals or studies their reactions
a person whose job is to prepare and sell medicines and other goods in a shop
a shop where you can buy medicines, make-up, and sometimes other things such as chocolate
chemist.chi_def: （出售藥品、化妝品等的）藥店，藥房

chemistry.eng_def: the scientific study of the basic characteristics of substances and the ways in which they react or combine
chemistry.eg: She studied chemistry and physics at college.

chemistry.eng_def: the basic characteristics of a substance and the ways in which it reacts or combines with other substances
chemistry.eg: A team of scientists has been studying the chemistry of the ozone layer.

chemistry.eng_def: a quality that exists when two people understand and are attracted to each other
chemistry.chi_def: （兩人間的）理解和吸引；相互吸引
chemistry.eg: The sexual chemistry between them was obvious.

cherish.eng_def: to love, protect, and care for someone or something that is important to you
cherish.eg: Although I cherish my children, I do allow them their independence.

cherish.eng_def: to keep hopes, memories, or ideas in your mind because they are important to you and bring you pleasure
cherish.chi_def: 珍藏，懷有（希望、記憶）；抱有（想法）
cherish.eg: I cherish the memories of the time we spent together.

cherry.eng_def: a small, round, soft red or black fruit with a single hard seed in the middle, or the tree on which the fruit grows

chess.eng_def: a game played by two people on a square board, in which each player has 16 pieces that can be moved on the board in different ways

chest.eng_def: the upper front part of the body of humans and some animals, between the stomach and the neck, containing the heart and lungs
chest.eg: He was shot in the chest at point blank range.

chest.eng_def: a large, strong box, usually made of wood, used for storing goods or possessions or for moving possessions from one place to another
chest.eg: Her books and clothes were packed into chests and shipped across to Canada.
